text: hi everyone Anthony Fantana here the
Internet's busiest music nerd and it's
time for review of the new idols album
idols idlest I don't see but I don't see
it down a sure prayer for tureen these
guys are a Brisbane metal outfit I first
heard about them a few years ago through
the release of their debut record
farewell all joy a record that I found
phenomenally intense and noisy however I
did not really find this LP that
memorable compositionally I do remember
the incredible sonic beatdown that this
record brought to the table and then how
it smashed the table that it brought it
to immediately after and even though I'm
usually impressed by that sort of thing
I really need a bit more in the way of a
finesse and in detail if the fact that
you sound like an atomic bomb is really
going to a translate to me and I feel
the band came through with exactly that
a little bit of finesse and some
experimentation on this latest record of
there's longer more multi-faceted songs
on this record that meld together
elements of grindcore metalcore
specifically the sounds of bands like
converge straight punk-rock noise rock
and now in a lot of the tracks on this
LP there are all of these freakish
saxophone solos screaming away creating
an insane ruckus buying the huge
pummeling walls of riffs on this LP you
might liken it to a shining record
except I think the riffs are a bit
heavier and the sax doesn't play as
strong of a roll or you might liken it
to maybe like one of John's or pne's
naked city records except this band is
obviously bringing Horne instrumentation
into its music from a metal and Punk
standpoint whereas when John was working
with Naked City he was toying with
grindcore metal and punk rock from an
avant-gardist point of view I wouldn't
say the experiment so boldly that this
record ever loses its momentum the band
pretty much focuses nearly every moment
on this LP on a strong heavy visceral
pummeling experience just like their
first record but I think they
out of their comfort zone enough to make
the 28 minutes that this record lasts a
bit more colorful and and hellish to the
performances on this LP guitars bass
drums vocals are all incredibly dizzying
they're dense they're compact everything
on this record happened so fast it's
really difficult to put your finger on
exactly what is going on on a first or a
second or even a third listen I mean the
abuse the sonic abuse that is going on
is very clear but how exactly it happens
you don't know it's sort of like being
blindfolded and then being beaten within
an inch of your life by a group of
masked assailants not that they need
masks you are blindfolded and this band
does not hesitate to make sure that that
message is sent loud and clear right
with the opening track here lied to the
longest track on this entire LP - at six
minutes or so and it seems like this
song was composed simply to be the most
soul-sucking piece of music that this
entire album has to offer really just
beats down all expectations that the
music that you're about to listen to
we'll be showing you any signs of
sunlight or anything sweet or anything
catchy and then with every track after
this one they just dragged you further
down and into that abyss this track goes
careening right into another that feels
like an extension of the opener with
these elongated horn and guitar riffs
just playing against one another it's
slow it's heavy and immediately after
this we have a trio of songs that are
maybe the most abrasive on the entire LP
blast beats heavy rips and freakish
vocals galore the screams are throw
searing the blast beats are just like
bombshell volume like I said earlier
it's clear that these guys have listened
to a bit of converge however I do think
they take these influences and bring a
much more freakish sound into the mix
which most definitely comes out on a
track like PCP crazy which is a more of
a weird yet slower and more
straightforward centerpiece in the
entire record where the band seems to be
playing up a bit of straightforward Punk
och sort of right at the beginning of
the track it's got all these strung out
guitars this really distorted grimy
bassline these vocals that are really
shouty and have a bouncy echo on them
reminds me a little bit of VOCs for
whatever reason and this marching snare
drum it's like they're a beat or two
away from segwaying right into a cow
punk song but instead they go right into
some blast beats right after these minor
interval riffs that go done and it ended
in it like a soundtrack the band makes
all these surprised transitions all over
this track something I wish they
experimented with a bit more on other
songs here but still it does make this
song a real highlight on the entire LP
if there's a spot on this record that
shows a strong naked city influence it's
it's most likely this one and this track
actually marks a pretty noticeable
change on the entire LP if you're hip to
the very abrasive subtleties of this
record pretty much all the songs after
this are a bit slower a bit more
brooding longer overall not quite the
under one minute or around one minute
mark like a few of the songs before this
point are there are Punk riffs on
steroids and some insane saxophones in
the background on the track Concord
Prison and the song pay with youth has
these really detailed fast animalistic
drums playing against a very steady
grimy bassline with some really noisy
guitars this track is sort of like
listening to converge collaborate with
the Jesus lizard or something like that
a combination that I think is even
clearer when listening to this track on
a demo that this band put out just a
year ago I think this record finishes
really strong overall - I mean it
finishes just as colorful and as noisy
and as exceptionally performed as it
started and even though every single
musical detail of what this band does is
not clear right from the get-go the
intensity of their playing and just the
layers man the layers of the riffs the
drums the bass the horns the really just
uh just blood-curdling vocals on this
thing
it's all just so overwhelming but
excitingly so even though these guys
occasionally do really where their
influence is on their sleeves
I'm loving this record this is just such
an intense ride I love the blend the Mel
the different genres that come together
on this thing and just how incredibly
extreme it is it's just so admirably
extreme I'm feeling a decent of strong 8
on this thing transition if you've given
this incredibly loud record to listen
and you didn't die in the middle of it
what did you think did you love it
did you hate it why what do you think I
